rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:1
rsbNotes.text: 10:1 Caesarea. Caesarea Maritima (Caesarea by the Sea) was a seaport on the Mediterranean sixty-five miles northwest of Jerusalem. It was rebuilt and improved on an ambitious scale by Herod the Great.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:2
rsbNotes.text: 10:2 feared God. A term that may indicate that Cornelius was partly converted to Judaism, a Gentile who worshiped God but who was not circumcised (13:16, 26).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:9
rsbNotes.text: 10:9 on the housetop . . . to pray. Peter probably prayed three times a day (cf. 3:1; Dan. 6:10); this was his midday prayer. Houses typically had flat roofs reached by an outside stairway.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:10
rsbNotes.text: 10:10 a trance. Peter’s consciousness was withdrawn from external things in preparation for the vision (cf. 22:17).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:12
rsbNotes.text: 10:12 all kinds of animals. Both clean and unclean animals (Lev. 11).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:13
rsbNotes.text: 10:13 kill and eat. Peter was unwilling to violate the Old Testament laws that prohibited eating unclean animals (v. 14).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:15
rsbNotes.text: 10:15 God has made clean. Through this vivid illustration, God told Peter that He had abrogated the laws of ritual cleanliness; see Mark 7:14–19.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 10:16
rsbNotes.text: 10:16 three times. The vision was repeated to impress Peter.
